title: 19-Year-Old Student with Longstanding Sensorineural Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I have difficulty hearing and understanding speech, which seems harder for me than hearing environmental sounds. I've had this problem as long as I can remember.

problem_summary.onset: Congenital or early childhood (as long as she can remember).
problem_summary.course: Stable; patient does not believe it is getting worse.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Loud speech production, monotonous vocal tone, distortion of sibilant sounds.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Academic difficulty increased upon entering college despite good grades in high school.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking help due to increased difficulty with schoolwork in college.

history.present_illness: 19-year-old college student reports longstanding hearing loss. Finds speech understanding difficult. Feels school is becoming harder due to hearing.
history.otologic_history: No history of ear infections. Never wore hearing aids.
history.medical_psych_history: No known family members with hearing loss.
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis and management of hearing difficulty affecting college performance.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral, symmetrical, sloping sensorineural hearing loss. Thresholds range from mild in the low frequencies to moderately-severe in the highs.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs agree with pure-tone averages. Word recognition scores are good but slightly reduced, consistent with cochlear loss.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Present but at low sensation levels (recruitment).

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: ABR: All waves prolonged, normal interpeak latencies, steep latency-intensity function. TEOAE: Absent. Tone Decay: Minimal/Negative.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, symmetrical, sloping mild-to-moderately-severe sensorineural hearing loss. Speech recognition is good (82-86%) but slightly reduced. Ancillary testing (low sensation level reflexes, steep ABR latency-intensity function, absent OAEs) is consistent with a cochlear site of lesion.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a permanent hearing loss in both ears that affects your ability to hear high-pitched sounds and speech clarity.
The results suggest the problem is in the inner ear (cochlea), likely something you have had for a long time.
I recommend a hearing aid evaluation to help you hear speech more clearly in your college classes.
We should also arrange a medical consultation to ensure there are no other medical issues and to discuss genetic counseling if you are interested.
notes_for_actor: Introduce some distortion when producing sibilant sounds (like 's' or 'sh').
Portray a student who is academically capable but frustrated by the increased listening effort in college.
